questions.text: What percentage of distribution is represented by one standard deviation in a normal curve?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: 

Option A. Option A (68%): In a normal distribution, approximately 68% of the data falls within one standard deviation of the mean. This means that the majority of the observations cluster around the mean, with a smaller proportion extending beyond one standard deviation in either direction.

Incorrect Options

Option B. Option B (34%): In reality, 34% of the data falls within half of one standard deviation from the mean, not the full one standard deviation.

Option C. Option C (99%):It represents a much larger range, which would be three standard deviations. In a normal distribution, about 99.7% of the data falls within three standard deviations of the mean, not within one standard deviation.

OptionD. Option D (95%): This also represents a larger range, which would be two standard deviations. In reality, about 95% of the data falls within two standard deviations of the mean, not within one standard deviation.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe a probability distribution that represents the likelihood of a specific number of events occurring within a specific time period?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Poisson distribution

Explanation:

  • The Poisson distribution is used to model the probability of a specific number of events occurring within a fixed time period or spatial area, given a known average rate of occurrence. It is typically applied in situations where events happen independently and randomly over time, such as the number of calls at a call center, accidents at an intersection, or infections in a population.

 

Binomial distribution (Option A): The binomial distribution models the number of successes in a fixed number of independent Bernoulli trials (e.g., flipping a coin or testing a drug's efficacy), where the probability of success is constant for each trial.

Gaussian distribution (Option B): The Gaussian (Normal) distribution is a continuous probability distribution that is used to model variables that tend to cluster around a mean. It is not specific to counting events within a time period.

Normal distribution (Option D): This is another term for the Gaussian distribution, which is used for continuous variables rather than discrete event counts over time.

questions.text: In order to evaluate the nutritional status of young children residing in rural and urban areas, a research study was conducted. The study revealed that out of the total sample, comprising 30 children from rural areas and 20 children from urban areas, a significant proportion were found to be malnourished. Based on this information, which of the following statistical significance tests would be the most suitable in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Chi-Square Test

Chi-Square Test is a non-parametric test used to study the association between two qualitative variables. In this scenario, in comparing malnutrition rates among children in rural and urban areas, it analyzes if there's a significant difference in proportions between the two groups.

Parametric Test

Description

Paired Student's T-test (Option B)

Used to compare means (± SD) in paired data from the same group of individuals before and after an intervention.

Unpaired Student's T-test

Used to compare means (± SD) in two different groups of individuals. The Z-test is a variant of the unpaired Student's t-test used when the sample size is > 30.

ANOVA (Option D)

Used to compare means (± SD) in more than two different groups of individuals.

Pearson correlation coefficient

Measures the linear association between two variables and can range from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).

Standard error of the mean (Option C): is a measure of the variability of sample means and is not directly applicable for comparing categorical variables or assessing differences between groups.

questions.text: In a population study, if the mean value is 200 and the standard deviation is 20, what percentage of the population will fall within one standard deviation of the mean?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) 180-220

  • In a normal distribution, approximately 68% of the data falls within one standard deviation of the mean.
  • Given that the mean is 200 and the standard deviation is 20, we can calculate the range within which 68% of the population will lie.
  • One standard deviation below the mean is 200 - 20 = 180. One standard deviation above the mean is 200 + 20 = 220.
  • Therefore, approximately 68% of the population will lie between 180 and 220.

questions.text: The variation in a data set is compared with that of another data set using?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Coefficient of Variation

  • The coefficient of variation (CV) is a statistical measure used to compare the variability of two or more data sets relative to their mean.
  • It is calculated by dividing the standard deviation of a data set by its mean and then multiplying by 100 to express it as a percentage.
  • It's beneficial for comparing data sets with different units, indicating which has more or less variability relative to the mean.

 

Variance (Option A): Variance is a measure of the spread or dispersion of a single data set, not a comparison between two data sets.

Standard error of mean (Option C): The standard error of the mean (SEM) measures the precision of the estimated mean of a data set, not for comparing variation between different sets.

Standard deviation (Option D): The standard deviation measures the spread within a single data set without directly comparing variation between different sets

questions.text: How is the calculation of one variable using another variable typically performed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B) Coefficient of Regression

  • The coefficient of regression, also known as the regression coefficient or slope coefficient, is used to calculate the relationship between two variables in a linear regression model.
  • It quantifies the change in the dependent variable per unit change in the independent variable, aiding in estimating or predicting one variable's value based on another's

.

The Coefficient of Correlation (Option A) measures the strength and direction of a linear relationship between two variables.

The coefficient of variation (Option C) measures relative variability between datasets, typically as a percentage, without involving the calculation of one variable using another.

The coefficient of determination (Option D) (R-squared) measures the proportion of variance explained by independent variables in a regression model, assessing goodness of fit without directly calculating one variable using another.

questions.text: What does a correlation coefficient of less than 0.5 signify?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Weak Correlation

  • When the correlation coefficient is less than 0.5 (but greater than 0), it indicates a weak correlation between the variables.
  • This means that there is a relationship between the variables, but it is not very strong or significant.
  • The strength and direction of the correlation increase as the correlation coefficient approaches -1 or +1.

 

Confidence interval of 95% (Option A): This option is incorrect because the correlation coefficient measures the relationship between variables, while confidence intervals estimate a parameter's likely range.

Not statistically significant (Option C): This option is incorrect because statistical significance refers to the probability that the observed correlation is due to chance.

Strong correlation (Option D): Strong correlations typically have coefficients closer to -1 or +1, indicating a more pronounced relationship.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best study design as per hierarchy of evidence?
questions.solution:
• Hierarchy of Evidence: Meta-analysis ranks at the top of the evidence hierarchy as it synthesizes data from multiple high-quality studies.
  • Combines Results: It pools results from randomized controlled trials (RCTs) or observational studies, increasing statistical power and reliability.
  • Best for Decision-Making: Used in evidence-based medicine (EBM) to guide clinical practice by summarizing large amounts of data.
  • Higher Level than RCTs: While RCTs provide strong evidence, a meta-analysis of multiple high-quality RCTs offers even stronger conclusions.

Hierarchy of Evidence in Clinical Research

In evidence-based medicine, study designs are ranked based on their reliability in guiding clinical decision-making.

Level

Study Design

Strength of Evidence

1a

Meta-analysis of RCTs

Highest - Combines data from multiple studies for stronger conclusions.

1b

Large RCT (Randomized Controlled Trial)

Strong - Best for causality, but single studies may have limitations.

2a

Cohort Study

Moderate - Observational, used for prognosis and risk factor assessment.

2b

Case-Control Study

Weaker - Retrospective, useful for rare diseases.

3

Cross-sectional & Case Series

Weak - Descriptive, no causal inference.

4

Expert Opinion & Case Reports

Weakest - No statistical comparison, potential bias.

 

Case control study (Option B): Incorrect because case-control studies are retrospective and prone to bias, ranking lower in the hierarchy.

 

Cohort study (Option C): Incorrect because while prospective cohort studies provide stronger evidence than case-control studies, they are inferior to RCTs and meta-analyses.

 

Large RCT (Option D): Incorrect because while RCTs are the gold standard for individual studies, a meta-analysis of multiple RCTs provides even higher-quality evidence.

questions.text: A study was done to assess nutritional status among young children in rural and urban areas. 40 children in rural and 30 children in urban areas were malnourished. Which of the following tests of significance is the most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer- Option A) Chi Square test

Explanation:

  • The Chi-Square test is used to determine whether there is a significant association between two categorical variables. In this case, the variables are "nutritional status" (malnourished or not) and "area of residence" (rural or urban). By comparing the observed frequencies (40 malnourished children in rural areas and 30 malnourished children in urban areas) with the expected frequencies, the Chi-Square test can assess if there is a significant difference in the distribution of malnourished children between rural and urban areas.

Parametric Test

Description

Paired Student's t-test (Option B ruled out)

Used to compare means (± SD) in paired data from the same group of individuals before and after an intervention.

Unpaired Student's t-test

Used to compare means (± SD) in two different groups of individuals. The Z-test is a variant of the unpaired Student's t-test used when the sample size is > 30.

ANOVA (Option D ruled out)

Used to compare means (± SD) in more than two different groups of individuals.

Pearson correlation coefficient

Measures the linear association between two variables and can range from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).

Standard error of the mean (Option C): Quantifies the variability of sample means around the true population mean.

Standard error of the mean = standard deviation / √ sample size

questions.text: What is the most effective method for graphically representing the fluctuations in disease occurrence within a specific geographical region?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option A- Line graph

Explanation:

  • A line chart is used for showing trends of events or incidence of cases over time. It has both rise and fall.

Fig. Line chart

Histogram: (Option B ruled out)

  • It represents the frequency of continuous variables or quantitative variables.
  • Height is a quantitative or continuous variable (can take many possible values and also in between values)
  • It can be expressed in decimals and there is no gap in between.

Ogive: (Option C ruled out)

Aka cumulative frequency curve is useful for understanding how quantities accumulate over time. By plotting cumulative vaccination completion data on an ogive, the clinic can easily visualize the total number of patients vaccinated up to each month and observe trends in the rate of increase in vaccinations.

  • There is no dip or no fall of the curve.
  • Cases are constantly increasing

Fig. Ogive

Tree diagram (Option D): It is a visual tool used to represent hierarchical relationships or branching structures. It is commonly used in decision analysis or to display the possible outcomes of a particular event. It is not typically used to plot changes in disease incidence over time. Therefore, the most appropriate option for plotting the changes in the incidence of a disease in a given area is a Line Graph.

questions.text: For which type of variables is the following data representation used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option C- Continuous

Explanation:

Histogram:

  • It represents the frequency of continuous variables or quantitative variables.
  • Height is a quantitative or continuous variable (can take many possible values and also in between values)
  • It can be expressed in decimals and there is no gap in between.

 Bar Diagram:

questions.text: Please determine the study design based on the following information:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer- Option C: Case control study

Explanation:
A case-control study starts by selecting participants based on the outcome (disease or no disease).

  • Cases: individuals who already have the disease/outcome.
  • Controls: individuals without the disease/outcome.

The study then looks backward to determine prior exposure to potential risk factors.

Since the selection is based on outcome status, and exposure is assessed retrospectively, this fits the definition of a case-control study.

Incorrect Options:

Prospective cohort study (Option A): Participants are selected based on exposure status and followed forward in time to see who develops the disease. This is incorrect because the selection here is based on outcome, not exposure.

Retrospective cohort study (Option B): Participants are again selected based on exposure status, but outcomes are assessed from past records. This is incorrect because there is no exposure-based grouping in this study.

Nested case control study (Option D): A case-control study conducted within a pre-existing cohort, where cases and controls are drawn from the same cohort. This is incorrect because there’s no mention of an existing cohort.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the difference in the incidence of asthma in children who are exposed to second-hand smoke and those who are not. If he wishes to express the additional incidence of asthma in the exposed children as a percentage, which of the following should he use?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer- Option C: Population attributable risk

Explanation:

  • Population attributable risk (PAR) measures the proportion of disease in the exposed group due to the exposure. It's expressed as a percentage, indicating the additional risk due to the exposure.
  • It considers baseline disease risk in the population.
  • Helps estimate potential disease reduction if exposure is eliminated or modified.

Measure

Definition

Calculation

Attributable Risk

Proportion of disease incidence attributable to a specific exposure or risk factor

Risk in exposed group - Risk in unexposed group

Relative Risk

Risk of a particular outcome in the exposed group compared to the unexposed group

Risk in exposed group/Risk in unexposed group

Population Attributable Risk

Proportion of disease cases in a population attributable to a specific exposure or risk factor

(Prevalence of exposure) x (Relative risk-1)/(1+ (Prevalence of exposure) x (Relative risk - 1))

Odds Ratio

Strength of association between exposure and outcome in case-control or retrospective studies

(Exposure odds in cases/Non-exposure odds in cases) / (Exposure odds in controls/Non- exposure odds in controls)

Unpaired Student's t-test (Option B)

Used to compare means (± SD) in two different groups of individuals. The Z-test is a variant of the unpaired Student's t-test used when the sample size is > 30.

ANOVA (Option A ruled out)

Used to compare means (± SD) in more than two different groups of individuals.

Pearson correlation coefficient

Measures the linear association between two variables and can range from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).

Chi-Square Test (Option C): It is a non-parametric test used to study the association between two qualitative variables.

Observational studies

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the value that appears most frequently in a set of data?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer Option B - Mode:

Explanation:

  • The mode is the value that appears most frequently in a dataset. It represents the value that occurs with the highest frequency. In the dataset [1, 2, 3, 3, 4, 5], the mode is 3 because it appears twice, which is more frequently than any other value.

Incorrect Options:

Median (Option A): It is calculated by arranging the variables in ascending order and taking up the middle value.

This applies when an odd number of variables are given, which is given by

The median is given for variables in even numbers by averaging the two middle variables.

Standard deviation (Option C): Measures the variation or dispersion of a set of values around the mean. The formula for calculation is σ = √(∑(x− x̄)2 /n).

Mean (Option D): It is calculated by summing all the variables and dividing the same by the total number of variables.

questions.text: Which statistical diagram represents the population change in a specific location from 1983 to 1989?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is C. Component bar graph.

A component bar graph, also known as a stacked bar graph, is a statistical diagram used to represent the composition or distribution of a whole over different categories or components. It consists of bars representing each category or component, stacked on top of each other to show the total value or size of the whole.

In the given scenario, where the diagram charts the population change over years from 1983 to 1989, a component bar graph would be an appropriate representation. Each bar in the graph would represent a specific year, and the different components of the bar would represent the population size or change in population within that year.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A. Histogram: A histogram is a statistical diagram that represents the distribution of continuous or grouped data. It consists of bars where the area of each bar corresponds to the frequency or relative frequency of data within a specific range or class. Histograms are typically used to analyze continuous variables, such as age or income, and are not suitable for representing population change over time.

Options B. Line diagram: A line diagram, also known as a line graph or time series graph, is used to represent the relationship or trend between two variables over a continuous period. It involves plotting data points on a graph and connecting them with lines. While a line diagram can show population change over time, it does not specifically represent the composition or distribution of the population across different categories or components.

OptionsD. Multiple bar graphs: Multiple bar graphs display multiple bars side by side to compare different categories or variables across different groups or time periods. While it can show population change over time, it does not represent the composition or distribution of the population within each year, as described in the scenario.

questions.text: A randomized control trial is being conducted in patients with direct inguinal hernia, to compare the outcomes of a new surgery 'A' and the gold standard surgery 'B'. The p-value of this trial is found to be 0.04. What can we conclude from this?

choices.text: Type Il error is small and we can accept the findings of the study
The probability of a false negative conclusion that operation A is better than B is 4%
The power of the study to detect the difference between operations A and B is 96%
The probability of a false positive conclusion that operation A is better than B is 4%

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - The probability of a false positive conclusion that operation A is better than B is 4%

  • This option correctly interprets the p-value of 0.04. The p-value represents the probability of obtaining results as extreme as the observed results under the assumption that the null hypothesis is true. In this case, it means there is a 4% probability of falsely concluding that operation A is better than B when, in fact, there is no significant difference between the surgeries. Therefore, option D is the correct interpretation of the given p-value.

Incorrect Options:

OptionA - Type II error is small, and we can accept the findings of the study:

A p-value of 0.04 doesn't offer direct insight into Type II error probability, making it unwarranted to assume it's small and accept the study findings.

Option B - The probability of a false negative conclusion that operation A is better than B is 4%:

  • The p-value of 0.04 doesn't directly reflect the probability of a false negative. It represents the likelihood of obtaining results as extreme as observed if the null hypothesis is true. Therefore, this conclusion can't be solely inferred from the given p-value..

Option C - The power of the study to detect the difference between operations A and B is 96%:

  • The p-value of 0.04 doesn't inform about the study's power, which requires details like sample size and effect size. Therefore, this conclusion can't be drawn solely from the given p-value.

questions.text: At a PHC, a medical officer provides treatment and counselling to diabetic patients. Their body weights are recorded before the intervention and again 6 months later, using the health register. Which of the following statistical tests is most appropriate to analyze the change in weight in this group?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Paired t-test:

Explanation:

  • The most appropriate statistical test to analyze the change in weight in the same group of diabetic patients before and after the intervention is the paired t-test, which compares the means of two related measurements from the same individuals.

  • Types of Parametric tests:

Parametric Test

Description

Paired Student's t-test

Used to compare means (± SD) in paired data from the same group of individuals before and after an intervention. (Option B)

Unpaired Student's t-test

Used to compare means (± SD) in two different groups of individuals. The Z-test is a variant of the unpaired Student's t-test used when the sample size is > 30.

ANOVA

Used to compare means (± SD) in more than two different groups of individuals. (Option C ruled out)

Pearson correlation coefficient

Measures the linear association between two variables and can range from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).
  • Types of Non-parametric tests

  • Chi-square test (Option A) is used to assess the association between two categorical variables. Since body weight is a continuous variable and we are comparing means, this test is not appropriate.
  • Independent t-test (Option D) is used to compare the means of two separate, unrelated groups. In this case, the same individuals are being measured at two different points in time, so the groups are not independent.

questions.text: In a hospital, patients are classified into three groups based on disease severity: mild, moderate, and severe. One patient is randomly selected from each group for a study. What type of sampling method is this?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Stratified random sampling:

Explanation:

  • This study employs Stratified Random Sampling by dividing patients into mild, moderate, and severe disease groups and randomly selecting individuals from each, ensuring adequate representation of all subgroups.

Random Probability Sampling Methods

Sampling Method

Description

Example

Simple Random Sampling

(Option A ruled out)

Selecting units purely by chance, ensuring each unit has an equal probability of being chosen.

Drawing names using random number generators or drawing lots.

Systematic Random Sampling

(Option B ruled out)

Selecting every nth unit from the population after a random starting point.

From a list of 1000 people and need a sample of 100, select every 10th person on the list after choosing a random starting point between 1 and 10.

Stratified Random Sampling

(Option C)

Dividing the population into subgroups (strata) and randomly sampling from each subgroup.

Dividing a population into age groups (e.g., 18-29, 30-49, 50+) and randomly sampling individuals from each age group

Cluster Random Sampling

(Option D ruled out)

Dividing the population into clusters and randomly selecting entire clusters to be included.

Dividing a city into neighborhoods (clusters) and randomly selecting a few neighborhoods. All residents in the selected neighborhoods are then included in the sample.

Multi-Stage Sampling

Combining several sampling methods in stages.

First, randomly select districts (simple random sampling), then within selected districts, randomly select schools (second stage), and finally, within selected schools, randomly select students (third stage)

questions.text: On January 1, 2024, an area with a population of 10,000 had 100 TB cases. During the year, 30 patients were cured and 10 died. Twenty new TB cases were reported, and 5 of them were cured before December 31, 2024. What is the incidence and prevalence of TB cases?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. 2 and 1.2

Explanation:

  • Incidence (new cases during the year) and prevalence (total cases at a specific point in time, here end of year):

Incidence:

  • Population at risk = Total population − existing cases on Jan 1 = 10,000 − 100 = 9,900
  • New TB cases during 2024 = 20
  • Incidence per 1,000 = (20 ÷ 9,900) × 1,000 = ≈ 2 per 1,000

Prevalence (Dec 31, 2024):

  • Remaining old cases = 100 − (30 cured + 10 died) = 60
  • Remaining new cases = 20 − 5 cured = 15
  • Total existing cases on Dec 31 = 60 + 15 = 75
  • Prevalence (%) = (75 ÷ 10,000) × 100 = 0.75% ≈ 1.2%

Term

Definition

Formula

Incidence

New cases during a defined period among at-risk population

(New cases ÷ Population at risk) × Multiplier

Prevalence

All existing cases (old + new) at a point in time

(All cases ÷ Total population) × Multiplier
  • Incidence → measures risk of developing disease.
  • Prevalence → measures burden of disease.

1.2 and 10 (Option B) – Incidence is not 1.2 per 1,000 here; prevalence is not 10%.

1.2 and 12 (Option C) – Neither matches the calculated values.

2 and 10 (Option D) – Incidence matches, but prevalence is not 10%, it’s about 1.2%.

questions.text: In a group, the mean blood glucose level is 105 mg/dL with a standard deviation of 10 mg/dL. Assuming a normal distribution, what is the expected range of blood glucose values for approximately 95% of the population?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. 85 – 125 mg/dL

Explanation:

In a normal distribution, approximately 95% of the population’s values lie within ±2 standard deviations (SD) from the mean.

  • Mean = 105 mg/dL
  • SD = 10 mg/dL
  • Range for 95% = Mean ± (2 × SD) = 105 ± 20 = 85 to 125 mg/dL.

For normally distributed data, proportions within SD multiples are standard: ~68% within ±1 SD, ~95% within ±1.96 (≈±2) SD, ~99.7% within ±3 SD (empirical rule).

101 – 110 mg/dL (Option B): This is a much narrower range (±0.5 SD), covering far less than 95% of the population.

90 – 125 mg/dL (Option C): The lower limit is off; this is Mean − 1.5 SD to Mean + 2 SD, not a standard 95% range.

95 – 115 mg/dL (Option D): This is only Mean ± 1 SD, covering about 68% of the population.

questions.text: In a study, an investigator compared the mean blood pressure and standard deviation between two independent groups. Which of the following is the most appropriate statistical test to assess the significance of the difference between the two means?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Unpaired t-test

Explanation:

  • The question describes two independent groups where the investigator is comparing mean blood pressure values. The correct statistical test for comparing the means of two independent samples is the unpaired (independent samples) t-test.

Unpaired t-test: A parametric test used to compare the means of two independent groups to determine if the difference is statistically significant.

Assumptions:

  • The two groups are independent.
  • The data is continuous and approximately normally distributed.
  • The variances of the two groups are equal (homogeneity of variance).

Advantages: Simple to apply when assumptions are met.

Limitations: Not suitable for non-normal or categorical data; use non-parametric alternatives like Mann–Whitney U test if assumptions fail.

Chi-square test (Option C): Used for association between categorical variables; not for comparing means of continuous data.

ANOVA (Option D): Used for comparing means among more than two independent groups.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence of steps in a Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Randomisation → Manipulation → Follow-up → Assessment:

Explanation:

  • A Randomized Controlled Trial is considered the gold standard in clinical research because it minimizes bias and ensures comparability between study groups.
    • Randomisation: Participants are assigned to intervention or control groups using random methods, ensuring equal distribution of confounding factors.
    • Manipulation (Intervention): The experimental treatment or procedure is applied to the intervention group.
    • Follow-up: Participants are monitored over time to observe effects and detect adverse events.
    • Assessment: Outcomes are measured and analyzed to determine the effect of the intervention.
  • Other sequences (Options A, C, D) wrongly order randomisation, intervention, or assessment steps, compromising study validity.

questions.text: A study is conducted to compare the mean hemoglobin (Hb) levels between two independent groups. Which statistical test is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Unpaired t-test

Explanation:

  • An unpaired t-test (also called an independent samples t-test) is used when:
    • The outcome variable is continuous (e.g., hemoglobin levels).
    • There are two separate, independent groups being compared.
    • The data is approximately normally distributed in both groups, and variances are equal (or adjustments are made if not).
    • This test determines whether the observed difference in means is statistically significant, beyond what might occur due to random variation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Paired t-test: Used for matched or related samples — such as pre- and post-treatment measurements in the same subjects, or matched pairs. Not suitable for unrelated groups.

Option C - Chi-square test: Compares categorical data frequencies, not continuous numerical means.

Option D - ANOVA : Compares means for three or more independent groups; not needed when only two groups are being compared.

questions.text: Which of the following is used to measure the degree of objective and target achievement, and assess the quality of results obtained in a health program?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Evaluation:

Explanation:

  • Evaluation systematically assesses the design, implementation, and outcomes of a program to determine effectiveness and inform decisions.
  • It focuses on measuring achievements versus objectives.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Planning involves program design.

Option B: Surveillance is ongoing data collection.

Option C: Monitoring is continuous tracking of activities but less comprehensive than evaluation.

questions.text: A new community intervention is initiated to reduce prenatal sepsis. Researchers allocate 20 Primary Health Centres (PHCs) to receive standard care and 20 PHCs to receive a community-based intervention. What type of study design is this?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Cluster-randomized control trial

Explanation:

  • A cluster-randomized control trial randomizes groups (here PHCs) rather than individuals, evaluating intervention impact on communities or clusters, suitable for public health interventions.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cross-sectional is observational at one time point.

Option B - Case-control is retrospective and individual-based.

Option C - Quasi-experimental lacks randomization, whereas this design includes it.

questions.text: In a district-level survey, the introduction of breast cancer screening showed an increased 5-year survival rate, but autopsy data revealed no change in mortality. What type of bias does this represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Lead time bias

Explanation:

  • Lead time bias occurs when earlier detection of disease (through screening) increases measured survival time without affecting the actual time of death, giving a false impression of benefit.

Incorrect Options:

Survival bias (Option A) relates to selection of survivors.

Berksonian bias (Option C) is related to hospital-based selection bias.

Detection bias (Option D) refers to differences in ascertainment or diagnosis rates between groups.

questions.text: Glasgow coma scale is a type of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Ordinal scale data

The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is used to assess the level of consciousness in a patient. It assigns scores based on three components:

  1. Eye opening (1 to 4)
  2. Verbal response (1 to 5)
  3. Motor response (1 to 6)

The total score ranges from 3 to 15, with higher scores indicating better neurological function.

Data Type:

  • The GCS is considered ordinal scale data because:
    • The scores indicate an order or rank (e.g., a score of 4 is better than 3 in motor response).
    • However, the difference between scores (e.g., between 3 and 4) does not necessarily represent an equal increment in consciousness level, which makes it ordinal rather than interval or ratio.

Nominal scale data (Option A): Used for categorization without any order (e.g., blood groups). GCS has an inherent ranking, so it is not nominal.

Alphanumerical data (Option C): Refers to data containing letters and numbers. GCS consists only of numerical scores.

Interval scale data (Option D): Involves ordered data with equal intervals between values (e.g., temperature in Celsius). GCS does not have equal intervals between scores, so it is not interval scale data.

questions.text: Calculate the median of the following data set: 2, 3, 4, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 4.5:

  • The median is the middle value of an ordered data set. Since there are 8 numbers, the median is the average of the 4th and 5th numbers (4 and 5). Thus, the median is (4 + 5) / 2 = 4.5.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C and D are incorrect as given above.

questions.text: A group of 80 people was studied to assess the effect of diet modification on mean cholesterol levels before and after the intervention. Which statistical test is most appropriate to compare the mean cholesterol levels before and after the diet modification?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Paired t-test:

  • The paired t-test is the most appropriate test for comparing the mean cholesterol levels before and after diet modification in the same group of individuals. This test accounts for the fact that the data are paired (pre- and post-diet modification) and assesses whether the mean difference is statistically significant.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - McNemar test: This test is used for paired nominal data, specifically to analyze the difference in proportions for matched pairs, such as yes/no responses before and after an intervention. It is not appropriate for comparing means.

Option C - Chi-square test: The chi-square test is used to analyze categorical data to determine if there is a significant association between variables. It is not suitable for comparing means, especially when dealing with continuous data like cholesterol levels.

Option D - Wilcoxon signed-rank test: This is a non-parametric test used to compare two related samples or repeated measurements on a single sample when the data does not follow a normal distribution. It is an alternative to the paired t-test when the data is not normally distributed.

questions.text: A statistician wants to study the effects of medicine in three groups: humans, animals, and plants. He selects randomly out of these three groups. Which type of sampling is performed here?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Stratified Random Sampling:

  • In the given scenario, the statistician is performing stratified random sampling. This approach involves dividing the population into distinct strata (humans, animals, and plants) and then selecting randomly from each stratum. This method ensures that each subgroup is represented in the study, allowing for a more detailed analysis of the effects of medicine across different types of organisms.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Simple Random Sampling: This method involves selecting individuals randomly from the entire population without considering any subgroups. In this scenario, simple random sampling would mean choosing any individual from the combined groups of humans, animals, and plants without distinguishing between them.

Option B - Systematic Sampling: This method involves selecting samples based on a fixed, periodic interval (e.g., every 10th individual). Systematic sampling is not described in this scenario since the selection process does not involve intervals or systematic patterns.

Option D - Cluster Sampling: This method involves dividing the population into clusters (groups) and then randomly selecting entire clusters for the study. The focus here is on the whole clusters rather than individual strata within those clusters.

questions.text: A study was undertaken to establish consumption of vegetarian and non-vegetarian diet with disease. Which statistical test should be done?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Chi-Square Test:

  • The Chi-Square test is used to determine if there is a significant association between two categorical variables. It compares the observed frequencies with the expected frequencies to see if there is a significant difference.
  • This is appropriate for analyzing the relationship between diet type (categorical) and disease status (categorical). It helps to determine if the distribution of disease is independent of the type of diet.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Paired t-test:

  • This test is used to compare the means of two related groups. For example, it could be used to compare pre- and post-treatment measurements in the same subjects.
  • This is not suitable for comparing categorical data (diet type) with disease status. It is more appropriate for continuous variables.

Option B - McNemar's Test:

  • McNemar's test is used for paired nominal data to determine if there are differences in proportions. It is often used in studies with a matched case-control design or in before-and-after studies where the same subjects are measured twice.
  • This test is not suitable for comparing two independent groups (vegetarian vs. non-vegetarian) in relation to disease status. It is used for paired data rather than independent groups.

Option D - Wilcoxon Rank-Sum Test:

  • This test, also known as the Mann-Whitney U test, is used to compare differences between two independent groups on a continuous or ordinal outcome when the data does not assume normal distribution.
  • This is not suitable for categorical variables like diet type and disease status. It is used for comparing continuous or ordinal variables.

questions.text: Identify the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Line diagram

Explanation:

  • The above-given graph is a line diagram/line chart. It depicts the trends of events or incidence of cases over time, showing both rises and falls.

Incorrect Options:

Histogram (Option B):

  • A histogram represents the frequency of continuous variables or quantitative variables.
  • It consists of a series of adjacent rectangles or bars, where the area of each bar corresponds to the frequency or relative frequency of the data within a specific interval or category.

Scattered diagram (Option C):

  • The scattered diagram represents a correlation between two continuous variables

  • It consists of a collection of points, each representing the value of one variable plotted against the value of another variable.

Frequency polygon (Option D):

  • The frequency polygon is obtained by joining the mid-points of the histogram blocks.

questions.text: What percentage of data falls within one standard deviation of the mean in a normal distribution?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- 68%

Explanation:

  • In a normal distribution, about 68% of the data falls within one standard deviation of the mean.

A Gaussian/bell-shaped curve showing normal distribution forms when the point of coincidence is equal to mean = median = mode ~ Normal distribution

In a standard normal distribution

  • Mean = Median = mode = 0
  • Standard deviation = 1
  • Total area under the curve = 1

If we draw the following line

  • Redline cuts the base at the distance of 1 standard deviation.
  • Pink line at +/- 2 standard deviation.
  • Green line at +/- 3 standard deviation.
  • The tail of the curve never touches the baseline.

Area under the curve

Observation covered

68.3% ~ 68% of observation

Mean +/- 2 SD

95.4% ~ 95% of observation (Option B ruled out)

Mean +/- 3 SD

99.7% ~ 99% of observation (Option D ruled out)

Mean +/- ∞SD

100% of observation

98% (Option C): 98% of the data in a normal distribution falls within 2 and 3 SD (~2.33 SD) of the mean.

questions.text:
In biostatistics, formula given below stands for?

(σ) =√ [ Σ(x - μ²/Ν]
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A) Standard Deviation

Explanation:

  • The standard deviation is a measure of the dispersion or variability of a set of values.
  • It quantifies how much the values deviate from the mean. The formula for calculating the standard deviation involves taking the square root of the average of the squared differences between each value and the mean.
  • Standard deviation is considered the most comprehensive and widely used measure of dispersion in statistical analysis.

Measures of dispersion

Definition

Calculation

Standard deviation (Option A)

Measures the variation or dispersion of a set of values around the mean.

σ = √(∑(x− x̄)2 /n)

Range

The difference between the highest and lowest values in a dataset.

Range = Maximum value - Minimum value

Mean deviation

Measures the average absolute deviation of data points from the mean.

Mean deviation = ∑ X - x̄ / n

Variance (Option B ruled out)

Measures the average of the squared differences from the mean.

Variance = σ2

Sample Mean (Option C): The sample mean is the average value of a set of observations or data points. It is calculated by summing all the values in the sample and dividing the total by the number of observations. The sample mean is often used as an estimate of the population mean.

Median (Option D): It is calculated by arranging the variables in ascending order and taking up the middle value.

This applies when an odd number of variables are given, which is given by

The median is given for variables in even numbers by averaging the two middle variables.

questions.text: 2 doctors were asked to report 100 X-rays and a Kappa value of 0.71; what is interpretation?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A) Good

Explanation:

Interpretation of a Kappa value of 0.71 between two doctors reporting 100 X-rays is considered Good, indicating a reliable level of agreement between the observers.

The Kappa statistic is a measure of inter-rater agreement or reliability between two observers. It ranges from -1 to 1, where:

  • 1 indicates perfect agreement
  • O indicates agreement expected by chance
  • -1 indicates perfect disagreement.

Kappa value

Inference

>0.75

Excellent (beyond chance)

0.4-0.75

Intermediate to Good

<0.4

Poor

questions.text: In order to investigate the dietary habits of the diverse population residing in the urban region of Delhi, a research study is being conducted. Which of the following methods can be utilized to acquire a representative sample for the study?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Stratified random sampling

Explanation:

  • In a diverse population, such as the one in urban Delhi, stratified random sampling is an effective method to ensure that different subgroups (or strata) of the population are represented in the sample.
  • In this case, the population can be divided into subgroups based on factors like socioeconomic status, age, dietary preferences, or geographic location within the urban region.
  • After dividing the population into strata, random samples are then taken from each group, ensuring that the sample is representative of the entire population.

 

Cluster random sampling (Option A): is incorrect because cluster sampling is used when the population is divided into clusters, often geographically, and entire clusters are randomly selected. While this can be used in large-scale studies, it doesn't specifically ensure representation of the diverse subgroups within the population as well as stratified sampling.

Simple random sampling (Option C): is incorrect because simple random sampling involves selecting individuals from the entire population randomly without considering any subgroups. While it may still give a sample, it may not adequately represent the diverse dietary habits of the population in urban Delhi.

Systematic random sampling (Option D): is incorrect because systematic random sampling involves selecting every nth individual from a list or a sequence of individuals. While it's easier to implement, it doesn't ensure that different groups within the population are represented as effectively as stratified sampling.

questions.text: In a patient, if a point-of-care diagnostic test with a sensitivity of 98% yields a negative test result, what does this indicate?

choices.text: The patient would need another point–of–care diagnostic test for the same clinical condition
The prevalence of the disease is 2%.
The patient is less likely to have the disease
The patient has been wrongly ruled out due to false negatives

questions.solution:
Correct Answer- (Option C)

Explanation

A high sensitivity test with a negative result indicates the patient is less likely to have the disease due to the low probability of a false-negative result.

 

The patient would need another point–of–care diagnostic test for the same clinical condition (Option A): A highly sensitive test that gives a negative result already provides strong evidence to rule out the disease, and further testing is generally unnecessary.

 

The prevalence of the disease is 2% (Option B): Sensitivity does not directly relate to disease prevalence; prevalence is the proportion of individuals in a population who have the disease.

 

The patient has been wrongly ruled out due to false negatives (Option D): With a sensitivity of 98%, the chance of a false-negative result is very low (only 2%).

questions.text: What is the branch of statistics dealing with method of data collection and counting?
questions.solution:
Correct answer- (Option B) Descriptive statistics

Explanation

Descriptive statistics involves the methods for collecting, organizing, summarizing, and presenting data in an informative way. This includes techniques such as counting, calculating averages, and representing data in charts, tables, or graphs. It focuses on presenting the data collected, such as through counts or frequency distributions.

 

Theoretical statistics (Option A) deals with the development of statistical models and methods, but it doesn't primarily focus on data collection or counting. It is more concerned with the mathematical foundations of statistical theory.

 

Analytical statistics (Option C) involves the process of using statistical methods to analyze and interpret data, especially through hypothesis testing, correlation, regression, etc. It goes beyond the initial counting and organization of data.

 

Inferential statistics (Option D) involves using sample data to make generalizations or predictions about a larger population. It includes methods like hypothesis testing, confidence intervals, and regression, but it doesn't focus on data collection and counting.

questions.text: Which of the following indicators can help determine whether the health system is important to identifying leprosy in the community?

choices.text: Annual new case detection rate per lac
Proportion of newly diagnosed patients with grade 2 disability

questions.solution:
Correct Answer- (Option B)

Explanation

This is the most relevant indicator for identifying leprosy in the community. It reflects the number of new cases detected per 100,000 people. A high rate of new case detection suggests an active effort to identify and diagnose cases early, which is crucial for effective control of leprosy in the community. Thus, it is an important indicator for evaluating how well the health system is identifying new cases.

 

Treatment completion rate (Option A): While this indicator is essential for assessing the success of leprosy treatment, it does not directly help in determining how well the health system is identifying new cases in the community. It is more about patient adherence to treatment after diagnosis.

 

Treatment initiation rate (Option C): This is important for assessing how quickly patients are started on treatment after diagnosis. However, it doesn't directly indicate the system's effectiveness in identifying new cases in the first place.

 

Proportion of newly diagnosed patients with grade 2 disability (Option D): This is more about the severity of the disease at diagnosis rather than how effectively the health system is identifying new cases. A higher proportion of patients with grade 2 disability indicates delayed diagnosis, which is a problem, but it doesn't directly measure case identification.

1. The female population is at greater risk of developing blindness.

2. People dwelling in rural areas are at increased risk of developing blindness

3. The risk of developing blindness increases with age

4. Illiteracy leads to an increased risk of developing blindness
questions.solution:
Correct Answer- (Option D)

Explanation

The risk of developing blindness increases with age (3): This is true. The odds ratios for each age group (>50 years) consistently increase, and all p-values are <0.001, indicating a strong and statistically significant association between age and the risk of blindness.

 

Illiteracy leads to an increased risk of developing blindness (4): This is true. The odds ratio for illiterate individuals is 1.2, and the p-value is <0.01, indicating a statistically significant association between illiteracy and a higher risk of blindness.

 

The female population is at greater risk of developing blindness (1): This is false. The odds ratio for females is 0.3, which indicates a lower risk compared to males, as a value less than 1 indicates a protective effect for females. The p-value is significant (<0.001), further supporting this finding.

 

People dwelling in rural areas are at increased risk of developing blindness (2): This is partially true, but the p-value of 0.1 for rural residence suggests that the result is not statistically significant, despite the odds ratio of 2.4 indicating a higher risk. Since the p-value is not below 0.05, this association is not conclusive.

questions.text: Which one of the options listed below is a non-parametric test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Friedman test

Explanation:

  • A non-parametric test is one that does not assume a specific distribution for the data, such as normality, and is typically used when the assumptions of parametric tests (like the t-test or ANOVA) are not met. The Friedman test is a non-parametric alternative to the repeated measures ANOVA, used to test differences between groups when the data is paired or repeated.

 

Student t-test (Option A): This is a parametric test, used to compare the means of two groups. It assumes that the data follows a normal distribution.

ANOVA (Option C): Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) is a parametric test used to compare means across three or more groups. It assumes normality and homogeneity of variance.

Pearson (Option D): The Pearson correlation coefficient measures the strength of a linear relationship between two continuous variables. It is parametric and assumes normality.

questions.text:
5-year old Ram and 3-year-old Sham are Rama Devi’s sons. Sham developed a rash, but Rama Devi ignored it, assuming it to be an allergy. After 10 days, Ram also developed a rash along with a fever. Out of fear, Rama Devi took Ram to the primary health center (PHC). The healthcare workers at the PHC suspected it to be measles. Choose all correct options from among the following:

1. Ram is an index case.

2. Sham is a primary case

3. Ram got the infection from Sham

4. Ram could have received post-exposure prophylaxis if his mother had brought him to the hospital when Sham got the rash.
questions.solution:
In the context of the scenario involving Ram and Sham, the correct options regarding their cases are:

Ram is an index case – This is correct because Ram is the first person in the scenario who prompted healthcare intervention.

Sham is a primary case – This is correct because Sham developed symptoms first, indicating he was likely the initial case.

Ram got the infection from Sham – This is likely correct, as Sham showed symptoms first, and Ram developed symptoms later, suggesting transmission from Sham.

Ram could have received post-exposure prophylaxis if his mother had brought him to the hospital when Sham got the rash – This is correct because timely intervention could have allowed for post-exposure prophylaxis to prevent measles.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a component of meta-analysis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Randomization

Explanation:

  • Meta-analysis is simply an analysis of results derived from multiple studies. It doesn't involve randomization because it synthesizes data from studies where randomization has already occurred, particularly in randomized controlled trials (RCTs).
  • It quantitatively and qualitatively analyses the results from various studies to reach a common conclusion. It differs from a systematic review in that the latter can be used to analyse the outcome of only a single study.
  • Meta-analysis takes the upper hand because the final outcome will always be reliable if multiple studies on the same topic are being analysed rather than a single study.

 

Incorrect Options:

Selection (Option A): Selection is a crucial step in meta-analysis. It involves identifying and selecting relevant studies that meet the inclusion criteria for the analysis.

Analysis (Option B): Analysis in meta-analysis involves extracting and synthesizing data from selected studies to obtain pooled estimates of treatment effects or associations through statistical methods.

Abstraction (Option D): In meta-analysis, abstraction involves extracting vital data from selected studies.

questions.text: A homogenous sample of 4 groups was taken as shown below. The height and weight of each group had a correlation coefficient of 0.6. What will be the total coefficient of correlation of the whole group?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Equal to 0.6

Explanation:

  • A correlation coefficient of 0.6 within each group indicates a positive relationship between height and weight.
  • If this relationship holds consistently across all groups, it suggests a strong positive correlation within the entire dataset.
  • This is depicted by tight clustering of data points along an upward-sloping trend line on the scatter plot.

The correlation coefficient is a statistical measure that describes the strength and direction of a relationship between two variables. It ranges from -1 to 1:

  • +1 means a perfect positive correlation (as one variable increases, the other also increases).
  • -1 means a perfect negative correlation (as one variable increases, the other decreases).
  • 0 means no correlation (no relationship between the variables).

 

Incorrect Options:

Less than 0.6 (Option B): If a positive correlation of 0.6 exists within each group, and it holds consistently across all groups, the total correlation for the entire dataset would be at least 0.6.

More than 0.6 (Option C): Total correlation might surpass 0.6, but without more details like group weights or sample sizes, we can't be sure.

Skewed coefficient of 0.6 (Option D): The term "skewed coefficient" typically refers to an asymmetrical distribution, not the correlation coefficient itself.

questions.text: Interpret the following graph (in order from left to right):

choices.text: Normal, negatively skewed, positively skewed, skewed with outliers
Normal, positively skewed, negatively skewed, normal with outliers
Normal, negatively skewed, positively skewed, normal with outliers
Skewed with outliers, positively skewed, negatively skewed, normal

questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Normal, positively skewed, negatively skewed, normal with outliers

 

Explanation:

 

  • 1- Normal Distribution: A whisker and box plot displays a normal distribution with a box from Q1 to Q3, showing the median as a line inside. The whiskers extend 1.5 times the IQR or to the maximum and minimum values within the range, with no outliers beyond them.

 

  • 2- Positively Skewed Distribution: In a positively skewed distribution, most data cluster at the lower end with a long tail towards higher values. The whisker and box plot reflects this by shifting the box towards the lower end, with the median closer. The longer whisker on the higher end accommodates the tail, with any outliers beyond it.

 

  • 3- Negatively Skewed Distribution: In a negatively skewed distribution, most data cluster at the higher end, with a long tail toward lower values. The whisker and box plot reflects this by shifting the box towards the higher end, with the median closer. The longer lower whisker accommodates the tail, with any outliers beyond it.

 

  • 4- Normal Distribution with Outliers: In a normal distribution with outliers, the box and whisker plot resembles a standard distribution, but with outliers plotted beyond the whiskers. These outliers deviate significantly from the majority of the data and may be shown as individual points or special symbols.

questions.text: Which of the following is used for graphical representation in flow cytometry analysis?
questions.solution:
C) Histogram, dot plot

 

Explanation:

 

  • The graphical representation for flow cytometry analysis is typically done using: Histogram, dot plot

 

  • Flow cytometry analyzes cellular properties like size, granularity, and fluorescence intensity. Data is represented using histograms, showing frequency distribution of parameters like fluorescence intensity, and dot plots, displaying two parameters per cell to identify subpopulations.

 

 

 

Incorrect Options:

 

Bar diagram, dot plot (Option A): While bar diagrams can be used to represent categorical or discrete data, they are not commonly used for flow cytometry analysis..

 

Line diagram, dot plot (Option B): Line diagrams are often used to depict trends over time, but in flow cytometry analysis, where data points represent individual cells and aren't time-dependent, they're not commonly employed.

 

Pie chart, dot plot (Option D): Pie charts display categorical data distribution but aren't suitable for flow cytometry analysis due to its focus on continuous variables and individual cells.

questions.text: You are initiating hypertension services at your Primary Health Center (PHC). 50 patients in need of antihypertensive treatment have been transferred from another facility. Among them, 40 were prescribed amlodipine (5mg orally) and 10 were prescribed lisinopril (10mg orally) due to contraindications with amlodipine. Medications are supplied monthly at the PHC, and you are responsible for ordering them. How many tablets do you need to order and what should be the reorder factor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) 1600, rf = 2

 

  • Total number of tablets required for the 50 patients:
  • Amlodipine: 40 patients * 5mg per day * 30 days = 6,000 mg
  • Lisinopril: 10 patients * 10mg per day * 30 days = 3,000 mg
  • Total tablets required:
  • Amlodipine: 6,000 mg / 5mg per tablet = 1,200 tablets
  • Lisinopril: 3,000 mg / 10mg per tablet = 300 tablets
  • Reorder factor (rf) = Total tablets required / Monthly supply
  • rf = 1,500 / 1,600 = 0.9375 (not equal to 2)

 

  • Based on the calculations, none of the options match the required number of tablets and reorder factor. However, from requirement is 1500 tablets and only one option has tablets more than 1500, ie option D, it is the most suitable answer.

 

Incorrect Options:

 

1000, rf=3 (Option A): 1,500 tablets / rf = 1,000 tablets, rf = 1,500 / 1,000 = 1.5 (not equal to 3)

 

1200, rf=2 (Option B): 1,500 tablets / rf = 1,200 tablets, rf = 1,500 / 1,200 = 1.25 (not equal to 2)

 

1400, rf=3 (Option C): 1,500 tablets / rf = 1,400 tablets, rf = 1,500 / 1,400 = 1.07 (not equal to 3)

Correct Answer A-

  • One standard deviation from the mean captures about 68% of the total data points.
  • This means that 68% of the values in a normal distribution lie within one standard deviation above or below the mean.

Mean +/- 1 SD

68.3% ~ 68% of observation

95.4% ~ 95% of observation (Option D)

99.7% ~ 99% of observation (Option C)

Mean +/- ∞SD

100% of observation

34% (Option B): is the percentage of the distribution that falls within the half standard deviation of the mean.

questions.text: What type of statistical diagram is used in the given text to illustrate the population change between 1983 and 1989 in a specific location?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Component bar graph

  • A Component bar graph, also known as a Stacked bar graph, displays the parts-to-whole relationship within a category.
  • It may not be suitable for depicting population change over time unless the population is divided into different components.

Types of bar diagrams:

Image

Explanation

Simple Bar Diagram

  • Simple bar diagrams represent the frequency of discrete variables like gender.
  • Discrete variables:These variables take fewer values and no in between values.
    • Examples: Religion, Blood groups

​​Compound Bar Diagram

  • There are gaps (discrete data) represented with multiple bars.
  • It is qualitative in the first quarter.
  • It is a Multiple bar diagram/Compound bar diagram.

Component Bar Diagram

  • Same bar has been divided into different components and each component represents its frequency.
  • It is a frequency of discrete variables.
  • It is known as the Component bar diagram.

 

 

Histogram (Option A)
  • It is not a bar diagram.
  • It represents the frequency of continuous variables or quantitative variables.
  • Height is a quantitative or continuous variable (can take many possible values and also in between values)
  • It can be expressed in decimals and there is no gap in between.

 

A line chart is used for showing trends of events or incidence of cases over time. It has both rise and fall. (Option B)

Line chart

Multiple bar graphs (Option D): as the name suggests, consist of multiple bars representing different categories or variables. They are typically used to compare values between different groups or categories, rather than tracking changes over time.

questions.text: Which method would be most effective in delivering statistical data to emphasize the significance of routine antenatal care for pregnant mothers, when educating a small, uneducated village during your rural posting?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Pictogram

  • Pictograms are the best way to present the data to the “man in the street” and those who cannot understand the orthodox charts i.e. to uneducated people as mentioned in the question.
  • Small pictures or symbols are used to present the data. Fractions of the picture can be used to represent the numbers smaller than the value of the whole symbol.

Histogram: (Option C)

  • It represents the frequency of continuous variables or quantitative variables.
  • Height is a quantitative or continuous variable (can take many possible values and also in between values)
  • It can be expressed in decimals and there is no gap in between.

Bar Diagram:

  • Simple bar diagrams represent the frequency of discrete variables like gender.
  • Discrete variables:These variables take fewer values and no in between values.
    • Examples: Religion, Blood groups
    • These are not represented in decimals so there are gaps.

Pictograph:

  • Used for graphical representation of qualitative variables
  • Used to teach something to a layman (illiterate).

Box and Whisker Plot:

  • A method of quantitative data representation.
  • Used to represent quartiles.
  • It comments on the type of distribution i.e., normal or skewed.
  • There is equal distribution on both sides (no outliers).
  • It is a normal distribution.
  • Tails are also equally distributed.

 

Frequency Polygon: (Option D)

  • It is drawn above a histogram.
  • Midpoints are joined by a straight line (frequency polygon).
  • Height is continuous (quantitative data).
  • If the number of observations is very large and group intervals are reduced, then frequency polygon loses its angulature and becomes a curve i.e., frequency curve.

A line chart is used for showing trends of events or incidence of cases over time. It has both rise and fall.(Option B)

Line chart

questions.text: Which methods are used to evaluate contraceptive failure?
questions.solution:
The Pearl Index is calculated as the number of pregnancies per 100 woman-years of exposure to a contraceptive method. It is a technique for evaluating contraceptive efficacy.

 

Formula

(Total accidental pregnancies / Total months of exposure) x 1200

Numerator

The total number of accidental pregnancies, including pregnancies that resulted in live births, stillbirths, abortions, or are ongoing.

Denominator

(Total months in the review period) – (months stopped using contraception for non-pregnancy reasons)

Minimum Data

At least 600 months of exposure.

Disadvantages
  • PI assumes a constant failure rate over time, but contraceptive failure rates typically decline with longer use.
  • High-fertility couples conceive earlier, skewing results towards lower-fertility couples later in studies.
  • PI ignores factors beyond accidental pregnancy that affect effectiveness, like user dissatisfaction, side effects, attempts to conceive, or loss of follow-up.

Better methods

Life Table Analysis is a better method to evaluate contraceptive efficacy.

It calculates cumulative failure rates over a specified time frame, like one

month.


 

Pharmacological index (Option A): There is no such index specifically used to evaluate contraceptive failure.

 

Performance index (Option C): This refers to an evaluation of overall performance, often in industrial or technical contexts, and is not used for contraceptive failure assessment.

 

Efficacy index (Option D): Although the term "efficacy" can relate to the effectiveness of contraceptives, there is no specific "efficacy index" used for evaluating contraceptive failure.
